DataElement.preferredName: Tumor Location Central Nervous System Tissue Type
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Text term to specify the location of the supratentorial tumor.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: the anatomic position of a tumor within an organ or system or within the patient as a whole.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: An abnormal tissue growth resulted from uncontrolled cell proliferation.  Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant ones exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia.  Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias. -- 2004

Concepts.definition: A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.

Property.preferredDefinition: Location; a point or extent in space.

Concepts.definition: A position, site, or point in space where something can be found.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: locations or structures in the human body.

DataElementConcept.changeDescription: 8/31/17 jk Transferred context, added RECIST CSI and reg status per Round 5 finalization task. --- revised and updated for ISO compliance; released

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: The main information-processing organs of the nervous system, consisting of the brain, spinal cord, and meninges._An anatomical structure consisting of similarly specialized cells and intercellular matrix, aggregated according to genetically determined spatial relationships, performing a specific function._Type; a subdivision of a particular kind of thing.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An operation in which a term denies or inverts the meaning of another term or construction.: Include or hold; have within or as a component.: A chronological written account of a patient's examination and treatment that includes the patient's medical history and complaints, the physician's physical findings, the results of diagnostic tests and procedures, and medications and therapeutic procedures. (dictionary.com)

Concepts.definition: An operation in which a term denies or inverts the meaning of another term or construction.
Include or hold; have within or as a component.

A chronological written account of a patient's examination and treatment that includes the patient's medical history and complaints, the physician's physical findings, the results of diagnostic tests and procedures, and medications and therapeutic procedures.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The nerve tissue forming the bulk of the deep parts of the brain and the superficial parts of the spinal cord.  It is composed of nerve cell processes, i.e. extensions (axons), which connect various grey matter areas of the brain to each other and carry nerve impulses to and from the nerve cell bodies within the central nervous system (neurons).  Cerebral and spinal white matter does not contain dendrites.  White matter is distinguished in that it is composed of axonal nerve fibers covered by a myelin sheath.

Concepts.definition: The nerve tissue forming the bulk of the deep parts of the brain and the superficial parts of the spinal cord. It is composed of nerve cell processes, i.e. extensions (axons), which connect various grey matter areas of the brain to each other and carry nerve impulses to and from the nerve cell bodies within the central nervous system (neurons). Cerebral and spinal white matter does not contain dendrites. White matter is distinguished in that it is composed of axonal nerve fibers covered by a myelin sheath.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The elongated, approximately cylindrical part of the central nervous system of vertebrates that lies in the vertebral canal and from which the spinal nerves emerge.|On-line Medical Dictionary

Concepts.definition: The elongated, approximately cylindrical part of the central nervous system of vertebrates that lies in the vertebral canal and from which the spinal nerves emerge.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The outer layer of the cerebrum composed of neurons and unmyelinated nerve fibers.  It is responsible for memory, attention, consciousness and other high mental functions.

Concepts.definition: The outer layer of the cerebrum composed of neurons and unmyelinated nerve fibers. It is responsible for memory, attention, consciousness and other higher levels of mental function.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The areas of the brain composed of neurons and (in contrast to the white matter) unmyelinated nerve fibers.

Concepts.definition: The areas of the brain composed of neurons and (in contrast to the white matter) unmyelinated nerve fibers.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Not known, observed, recorded; or reported as unknown by the data contributor.

Concepts.definition: Not known, observed, recorded; or reported as unknown by the data contributor.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: locations or structures in the human body.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: The main information-processing organs of the nervous system, consisting of the brain, spinal cord, and meninges.:An anatomical structure consisting of similarly specialized cells and intercellular matrix, aggregated according to genetically determined spatial relationships, performing a specific function.:Type; a subdivision of a particular kind of thing.

Concepts.definition: The part of the nervous system that consists of the brain, spinal cord, and meninges.
An anatomical structure consisting of similarly specialized cells and intercellular matrix, aggregated according to genetically determined spatial relationships, performing a specific function.
Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.
